text: I think I spent a lot of time talking
about different ideas I had and then
when I decided to start this company I
really just got down to work and really
just managed to take the time and the
tenets you have to be tenacious but you
have to find your passion and I think
once you do that it sort of has this
effect where it just continues the
momentum and and that's something that I
talk to entrepreneurs a lot about it's
finding your passion and then knowing
it's gonna be a tremendous amount of
work did it feel like a big risk it did
it did on many levels but even just
putting my name out there and I had
never designed I had never run a
business so it was all a risk and it was
learning on the job and I spent the last
nine years really learning about about
how to be a great manager how to expand
globally so many issues come our way and
as the business gets bigger it becomes
more complex what gave you the
confidence to think you could do it
because you had you dreamed big right
from the beginning I did sometimes I
hear some of the things I said and I
can't even believe it I said I wanted to
build a global lifestyle brand to start
a foundation and that was shocking
hearing him because I had no idea what
that meant and I think in retrospect
thinking about everything we've been
through which we've been through a lot
of challenges over the last nine years
it's been an incredible learning curve
as well and how do you take difficult
situations turn it into a positive and
move it forward one of your tips to
young entrepreneurs is that you need to
have a thicker skin I was wondering if
you think this is something that's
particularly relevant for women I think
it is and and you know more relevant
when I started the business I did I
realize the relevance I think when when
I grew up I grew up with three brothers
I didn't realize there were challenges
for women or girls and and as I got into
the workforce I started to see small
challenges but when I started our
business that's when the challenges
really kicked in what kind of hurdles
did you encounter do you think that
perhaps a man might not have done a bit
of condescending attitude and and and I
as I said I didn't I don't pay attention
to that and my parents said when I
started the company you need to thicken
your skin because there's gonna be
things that are written about you
there's gonna be
challenges that you're never going to
imagine and you just have to believe in
what you're doing and continue to follow
that path Tory do you think as we look
at this BBC series on 100 women do you
think there are differences in the way
that men and women manage businesses I
do I think I think businesses are often
better when they have both and it's not
just about women it's about having
different perspectives I see in our
business I would say out of 2,300
employees with 80% women and and I see
the leadership skills I see the
collaboration I see women supporting
other women and and and really helping
them further their careers and that's
something that I think women do I don't
have the experience that women are
competitive and jealous I have the
experience of women supporting other
women all the things women could improve
on learn perhaps from what men do of
course but I think men have a way of
really believing in themselves and I
think women have to be able to do that
more believing in their self-worth and
their abilities and also being able to
be their best advocates I think that's
important and that's often hard for me
as well as how do you go into any
situation and really be strong confident
and know your self-worth great tory
burch thank you very much thank you very
much
